metadata.title: Comprehensive State-by-State Directory of Rainwater Harvesting Laws and Regulations
metadata.dataSource: State and federal regulatory agencies, NCSL, DOE
metadata.summary: Rainwater harvesting is legal in all 50 US states, though regulations vary significantly. Western states like Colorado and Utah have historically restricted collection due to water rights concerns, but have relaxed rules in recent years. States like Texas, Virginia, Arizona, and Rhode Island actively encourage rainwater harvesting through tax credits and rebates. Most states have no restrictions on residential rainwater collection for outdoor irrigation, while indoor and potable use may require permits or professional design in some jurisdictions.

keyRestrictions: Indoor potable use requires treatment to drinking water standards
Alabama.summary: Alabama has no state restrictions on rainwater harvesting. Collection is approved and encouraged for residential use. Outdoor non-potable uses like irrigation and gardening have no requirements. Indoor use and potable applications must meet drinking water treatment standards through the Clean Water State Revolving Fund program.

keyRestrictions: Climate may limit practical collection in many areas
Alaska.summary: Alaska has no regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. The State Legislature has recommended rainwater harvesting as an alternative water source, particularly for rural communities. An estimated 30,000-60,000 residents already rely on rainwater as their primary water supply. Climate extremes may limit feasibility in some regions.

keyRestrictions: Must use on property where collected
Tucson requires 50% rainwater for new commercial outdoor irrigation
Arizona.recentChanges: Tucson became first US city to require rainwater harvesting for commercial buildings (2010)
Arizona.taxIncentives: Level 1 grants (50% or $500 max); Level 2 grants (up to $2,000); 25% tax credit available
Arizona.summary: Arizona is a national leader in rainwater harvesting support. No permit required for residential rooftop collection to rain barrels or cisterns. The City of Tucson became the first US location to require new commercial buildings to use rainwater for at least 50% of outdoor irrigation. State offers grants up to $2,000 and tax credits for system installation. Indoor non-potable use acceptable with proper filtration and disinfection.

keyRestrictions: Non-potable use only
Indoor systems must be designed by licensed professional engineer
Must comply with state plumbing code
Arkansas.summary: Arkansas allows rainwater harvesting for non-potable purposes. Outdoor use for lawns and gardens is unrestricted. Indoor non-potable systems must be designed by a professional engineer licensed in Arkansas and comply with state plumbing code requirements. Potable use is not permitted under current regulations.

California.governingCode: Rainwater Capture Act of 2012, California Water Code §10570-10574
keyRestrictions: Spray irrigation systems up to 360 gallons no permit
Non-spray outdoor up to 5,000 gallons no permit
Larger systems require permits
Requirements vary by local jurisdiction
California.recentChanges: Rainwater Capture Act of 2012 established statewide framework
California.summary: California strongly encourages rainwater harvesting through the Rainwater Capture Act of 2012. Residential, commercial, and governmental landowners may install and operate rainwater capture systems. Systems under 360 gallons for spray irrigation or 5,000 gallons for non-spray outdoor use typically don't require permits. Many local water agencies offer rebates for rain barrels and cisterns. Indoor non-potable use and potable applications may require additional permits depending on jurisdiction.

keyRestrictions: Maximum two containers
Combined capacity not to exceed 110 gallons
Single-family residences or up to 4-unit buildings only
Outdoor use only - no indoor use
No potable use
Colorado.recentChanges: House Bill 16-1005 (2016) legalized limited residential collection
Colorado.summary: Colorado historically prohibited rainwater collection due to prior appropriation water rights doctrine. In 2016, House Bill 16-1005 legalized limited residential rainwater harvesting. Residents may now collect rainwater in up to two containers with a combined maximum of 110 gallons. Collection is limited to single-family homes or buildings with up to four units. Water may only be used outdoors for lawn and garden irrigation - indoor and potable use remains prohibited.

keyRestrictions: Outdoor-only systems typically don't require permits
Indoor use regulated by local jurisdiction
Connecticut.primaryAgency: Connecticut Department of Energy and Environmental Protection
Connecticut.taxIncentives: Rain barrel rebate programs in some cities
Connecticut.summary: Connecticut has no state restrictions on rainwater harvesting for residential or commercial properties. Outdoor-only systems typically don't require permits. Indoor non-potable use may require local approval depending on jurisdiction. Some municipalities offer rain barrel rebate programs to encourage conservation.

keyRestrictions: Indoor connections require permit
Licensed plumber required for indoor connections
Delaware.primaryAgency: Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control
Delaware.taxIncentives: Runoff reduction credit consideration for stormwater management
Delaware.summary: Delaware supports rainwater harvesting with minimal restrictions. Outdoor collection and use is unrestricted. Indoor connections require a permit and must be installed by a licensed plumber. Rainwater harvesting systems may qualify for runoff reduction credits in stormwater management calculations.

keyRestrictions: Simple setups typically don't require permits
Larger systems may require permits
Requirements vary by municipality
Key West requires ARCSA standards compliance
Florida.taxIncentives: Some cities offer rebates for non-residential systems
Florida.summary: Florida encourages rainwater harvesting with flexible regulations. Simple rain barrel setups typically don't require permits. Larger systems and commercial applications may need permits depending on municipality. Both potable and non-potable use is allowed with proper system design. Key West specifically requires ARCSA (American Rainwater Catchment Systems Association) standards compliance. Some cities offer rebates for non-residential installations.

Georgia.governingCode: Georgia Department of Natural Resources regulations
keyRestrictions: Outdoor use typically unrestricted
Regulated by Department of Natural Resources
City of Atlanta allows potable systems with permits
Georgia.recentChanges: 25% income tax credit for water efficiency equipment
Georgia.taxIncentives: 25% income tax credit up to $2,500 for water efficiency equipment
Georgia.summary: Georgia supports rainwater harvesting with a generous 25% income tax credit up to $2,500 for water efficiency equipment including rainwater systems. Outdoor use for irrigation is unrestricted and doesn't require permits. Indoor non-potable use is allowed. The City of Atlanta permits potable rainwater systems with proper permitting. Regulations are administered by the Department of Natural Resources.

keyRestrictions: Homeowner-operated systems not state-regulated
Hawaii.recentChanges: Pending income tax credit bill under consideration
Hawaii.summary: Hawaii has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. An estimated 30,000-60,000 residents already use rainwater catchment systems as their primary water source, particularly in rural areas. Both potable and non-potable use is permitted. Homeowner-operated systems are not subject to state regulation. A tax credit bill is under consideration to further encourage adoption.

keyRestrictions: Cannot impact existing water rights
May require beneficial use permit for some applications
Excludes surface water collection
Idaho.summary: Idaho allows rainwater harvesting for any beneficial use, but systems must not impact existing water rights under the state's prior appropriation doctrine. Rooftop collection is generally permitted, but surface water collection is excluded. Some applications may require a beneficial use permit from the Department of Water Resources.

keyRestrictions: Non-potable use only
Indoor use must comply with State Plumbing Code
Illinois.summary: Illinois allows rainwater harvesting for non-potable purposes only. Outdoor irrigation use has minimal restrictions. Indoor non-potable applications must comply with the State Plumbing Code. Rainwater harvesting is recognized as a green infrastructure practice. Potable use is not permitted under current regulations.

keyRestrictions: Indoor non-potable use covered in building code
Indiana.taxIncentives: Some cities offer rain barrel programs
Indiana.summary: Indiana has no restrictions on rainwater harvesting. The 2020 Residential Code Chapter 29 addresses indoor non-potable use. Outdoor irrigation is unrestricted. Some cities offer rain barrel distribution or rebate programs to encourage conservation.

Iowa.taxIncentives: Some cities offer rain barrel rebates
Iowa.summary: Iowa has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is permitted without permits. Some cities offer rain barrel rebate programs to encourage water conservation and stormwater management.

approvedUses: Domestic use (household, livestock, up to 2 acres irrigation)
keyRestrictions: Domestic uses exempt from permit
Non-domestic uses may require permit
Prior appropriation water rights apply
Kansas.primaryAgency: Kansas Department of Agriculture - Division of Water Resources
Kansas.taxIncentives: Recommended as stormwater best management practice
Kansas.summary: Kansas allows rainwater harvesting under its water appropriation framework. Domestic uses including household needs, livestock watering, and irrigation up to 2 acres are exempt from permit requirements. Non-domestic or larger scale uses may require a water appropriation permit. Prior appropriation water rights doctrine applies to larger systems.

keyRestrictions: No permit required for agricultural use
Kentucky.taxIncentives: On-Farm Water Management Program funding; city grants for water quality projects
Kentucky.summary: Kentucky has no restrictions on rainwater harvesting. Agricultural use is particularly supported through the On-Farm Water Management Program which provides funding assistance. No permits are required for residential or agricultural rainwater collection. Some cities offer grants for water quality improvement projects including rainwater harvesting.

keyRestrictions: Containers must be sealed or screened to prevent mosquito breeding
Louisiana.summary: Louisiana allows rainwater harvesting without permits for outdoor irrigation and gardening. The primary requirement is that collection containers must be sealed or screened to prevent mosquito breeding - an important consideration given the state's climate. No permits are required for residential collection.

keyRestrictions: Encouraged as low-impact development for non-residential
Maine.summary: Maine has no regulations restricting personal residential rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is permitted without permits. Rainwater harvesting is encouraged as a low-impact development practice for non-residential properties.

keyRestrictions: Indoor use limited to non-potable applications
May require permit for indoor connections
Maryland.taxIncentives: Promoted as stormwater best management practice
Maryland.summary: Maryland encourages rainwater harvesting as a stormwater best management practice. Outdoor irrigation is unrestricted. Indoor non-potable use for toilets, cleaning, and laundry is permitted but may require permits for indoor plumbing connections. Potable use is not permitted.

Massachusetts.taxIncentives: Rain barrel discount programs in various cities
Massachusetts.summary: Massachusetts encourages rainwater harvesting with no state restrictions. Basic outdoor and indoor non-potable systems don't require permits. Various cities offer rain barrel discount programs to promote conservation. The practice is supported as a water conservation and stormwater management tool.

keyRestrictions: Indoor systems covered by 2018 Plumbing Code Appendix A
May require permit for indoor systems
Michigan.recentChanges: 2018 Plumbing Code updated to include rainwater harvesting provisions
Michigan.primaryAgency: Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy
Michigan.taxIncentives: Eligible as green infrastructure project for state funding
Michigan.summary: Michigan encourages rainwater harvesting and recognizes it as eligible green infrastructure for state funding. The 2018 Plumbing Code Appendix A provides guidance for indoor non-potable systems. Outdoor irrigation is unrestricted. Indoor systems may require permits depending on local jurisdiction.

keyRestrictions: Outdoor-only use requires no permit
Indoor non-potable systems require permit
Licensed professional installation required for indoor systems
Minnesota.summary: Minnesota allows rainwater harvesting with a tiered approach. Outdoor irrigation use requires no permit. Indoor non-potable systems require a permit and licensed professional installation. Rainwater harvesting is recognized as a stormwater best management practice.

Mississippi.taxIncentives: Recommended for stormwater management and pollution prevention
Mississippi.summary: Mississippi has no state-specific codes restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection is encouraged for stormwater management and pollution prevention. Both outdoor and indoor use is permitted without specific state restrictions.

Missouri.governingCode: Missouri Department of Natural Resources rules
keyRestrictions: Must comply with Department of Natural Resources rules
Missouri.summary: Missouri explicitly protects landowner rights to rainwater harvesting. State law declares that 'all Missouri landowners retain the right to have, use, and own systems for rainwater collection anytime and anywhere on their own property.' Both potable and non-potable use is permitted, subject to Department of Natural Resources rules.

keyRestrictions: Systems greater than 0.1 acre-feet require DNRC contact
Containers must be mosquito-proof
Montana.primaryAgency: Montana Department of Natural Resources and Conservation
Montana.summary: Montana allows rainwater harvesting for lawn and garden irrigation. Small residential systems are unrestricted, but systems with capacity greater than 0.1 acre-feet (about 32,500 gallons) must contact the Department of Natural Resources and Conservation. Collection containers must be mosquito-proof.

Nebraska.primaryAgency: Nebraska Department of Environment and Energy
Nebraska.taxIncentives: Some cities offer rain barrel programs
Nebraska.summary: Nebraska has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is unrestricted. Some cities offer rain barrel distribution or rebate programs to encourage water conservation.

keyRestrictions: Single-family dwellings only
Rooftop collection to rain barrels or cisterns
Non-potable domestic use only
Nevada.summary: Nevada legalized residential rainwater harvesting in 2017 through Assembly Bill 138. Single-family homeowners may collect rainwater from rooftops into rain barrels or cisterns without a permit. Water may be used for non-potable domestic purposes including lawn irrigation, livestock watering, vehicle washing, and toilet flushing. Potable use is not permitted.

New Hampshire.governingCode: No state restrictions for outdoor use
keyRestrictions: Indoor use covered in building codes
New Hampshire.primaryAgency: New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services
New Hampshire.taxIncentives: Soak Up the Rain program encourages conservation
New Hampshire.summary: New Hampshire has no restrictions on rainwater harvesting for outdoor use. Indoor non-potable applications are covered in building codes. The state's 'Soak Up the Rain' program actively encourages rainwater collection and other conservation practices.

New Jersey.primaryAgency: New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection
New Jersey.summary: New Jersey has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. The practice is encouraged as a stormwater best management practice. Rutgers University and other institutions provide resources and guidance promoting rainwater collection for residents.

New Mexico.governingCode: New Mexico Office of State Engineer guidance
keyRestrictions: Harvested rainwater may not be appropriated for other uses
Limited to domestic and landscape purposes
New Mexico.primaryAgency: New Mexico Office of the State Engineer
New Mexico.summary: New Mexico actively supports rainwater harvesting through the Office of the State Engineer. No permit is required for domestic residential or commercial use, including landscape irrigation up to 1 acre. Harvested rainwater may only be used for domestic and landscape purposes and cannot be appropriated for other uses under water rights law.

New York.primaryAgency: New York State Department of Environmental Conservation
New York.taxIncentives: Rain barrel rebate programs in multiple cities; NYC rain barrel giveaway program
New York.summary: New York has no state laws restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection is encouraged and supported through various local programs. Multiple cities offer rain barrel rebates. New York City has a rain barrel giveaway program providing free barrels to residents. Indoor non-potable use is permitted.

keyRestrictions: State law prohibits local governments from banning cistern use
North Carolina.recentChanges: 2009 law explicitly protects rainwater harvesting from local bans
North Carolina.primaryAgency: North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality
North Carolina.summary: North Carolina strongly supports rainwater harvesting. A 2009 law explicitly states that 'no state, county or local building code, or regulation from prohibiting the use of cisterns.' No permit is required for collection. Indoor use including toilet flushing is permitted. The state provides water conservation incentives for rainwater systems.

North Dakota.primaryAgency: North Dakota Department of Environmental Quality
North Dakota.summary: North Dakota has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection is unrestricted and is recognized as valuable for drought preparedness in the region.

keyRestrictions: Private water systems require permit
Must comply with Ohio Administrative Code
Ohio.summary: Ohio allows rainwater harvesting for both potable and non-potable use. Systems serving as private water systems must obtain permits and comply with Ohio Administrative Code Rule 3701-28-12. The code specifically addresses rainwater as an approved water source when properly treated.

Oklahoma.summary: Oklahoma has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is unrestricted for residential and domestic purposes.

Oregon.governingCode: Oregon Revised Statutes, water law exemptions
approvedUses: Any beneficial use from rooftop collection
keyRestrictions: Must be rooftop collection only
Surface water collection requires permit
Portland requires minimum 1,500 gallon cistern capacity
Oregon.summary: Oregon encourages rainwater harvesting from rooftops as an exempt use that doesn't require a water permit. Oregon's water laws are based on prior appropriation, but rooftop collection is specifically exempted. Surface water collection still requires a permit. Portland's building code requires cisterns to have a minimum 1,500 gallon capacity.

Pennsylvania.summary: Pennsylvania has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. The practice is encouraged for stormwater management. Philadelphia offers stormwater fee credits for properties that implement rainwater harvesting and other green infrastructure.

Rhode Island.governingCode: Rhode Island House Bill 7070 (2012), Plumbing Code
keyRestrictions: Collection only from above-ground impervious roof surfaces
Approved roofing materials only
Rhode Island.recentChanges: House Bill 7070 (2012) created tax credit incentive
Rhode Island.primaryAgency: Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management
Rhode Island.taxIncentives: 10% state income tax credit for cistern installation
Rhode Island.summary: Rhode Island encourages rainwater harvesting through a 10% state income tax credit for cistern installation, established by House Bill 7070 in 2012. The plumbing code specifies that rainwater may only be collected from above-ground impervious roof surfaces made of approved materials. Both individuals and businesses are eligible for the tax credit.

South Carolina.primaryAgency: South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control
South Carolina.summary: South Carolina has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is encouraged without permits. The practice is promoted as a water conservation and stormwater management tool.

South Dakota.primaryAgency: South Dakota Department of Agriculture and Natural Resources
South Dakota.summary: South Dakota has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is unrestricted for residential and domestic purposes.

Tennessee.primaryAgency: Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation
Tennessee.summary: Tennessee has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is unrestricted for residential and domestic purposes.

Texas.governingCode: Texas Tax Code §151.355, Texas Health and Safety Code §341.042
keyRestrictions: System must be incorporated into building design for new construction
Must provide municipal notice for potable systems
Financial institutions cannot prohibit rainwater harvesting
Texas.recentChanges: Sales tax exemption for rainwater harvesting equipment
Texas.taxIncentives: Sales tax exemption on rainwater harvesting equipment; Property tax exemptions available
Texas.summary: Texas is a national leader in rainwater harvesting support. State law provides sales tax exemptions for rainwater harvesting equipment and allows property tax exemptions for water conservation systems. Financial institutions are prohibited from refusing loans based on rainwater harvesting systems. New construction must incorporate rainwater systems into building design. Potable use requires municipal notification. Texas A&M AgriLife Extension provides extensive guidance and resources.

keyRestrictions: Maximum 2,500 gallons with registration
Maximum 200 gallons (two 100-gal containers) without registration
Must register systems over 200 gallons with Division of Water Rights
Must be used for beneficial purpose
Utah.summary: Utah allows rainwater harvesting with specific volume limits based on registration status. Unregistered collection is limited to two containers up to 100 gallons each (200 gallons total). Registered systems may collect up to 2,500 gallons. Registration is free and done through the Division of Water Rights. Water must be used for beneficial purposes on the property where collected.

Vermont.summary: Vermont has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is unrestricted for residential and domestic purposes.

Virginia.recentChanges: Senate Bill 1416 established comprehensive tax credit program
Virginia.taxIncentives: 50% tax credit up to $2,000 (residential) or $50,000 (commercial); $4/gallon reimbursement up to $20,000 for tanks over 250 gallons
Virginia.summary: Virginia strongly encourages rainwater harvesting through generous tax incentives established by Senate Bill 1416. Residents can receive a tax credit of up to 50% of installation costs, capped at $2,000 for individuals and $50,000 for corporations. Systems with tanks over 250 gallons may qualify for reimbursement of $4 per gallon of roof runoff capacity, up to $20,000. No permit required for collection.

Washington.summary: Washington state allows rainwater harvesting without restriction for the average homeowner. Collection is legal and non-encumbered for residential use. The Department of Ecology provides policy guidance supporting the practice. Some local jurisdictions offer incentive programs.

West Virginia.primaryAgency: West Virginia Department of Environmental Protection
West Virginia.summary: West Virginia has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is unrestricted for residential and domestic purposes.

Wisconsin.summary: Wisconsin has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is unrestricted for residential and domestic purposes.

Wyoming.summary: Wyoming has no state regulations restricting rainwater harvesting. Collection and use is unrestricted for residential and domestic purposes despite the state's prior appropriation water rights system.
